bibl.title: Letter from Albert G. Love to Philip Showalter Hench, November 26, 1951

div1.p: Love informs Hench that he was missed at the Walter Reed Memorial Association meeting. He read Hench's letter to Standlee, in which he questioned the reliability of her information, but does not think anyone will be able to convince her that Reed deserves all the recognition he has received.

div1.head: Letter from Albert G. Love to Philip Showalter Hench, November 26, 1951
div1.opener:
2709 Wisconsin Ave. NW
Washington 7, D. C.
Nov 26, 1951
Dr Philip S. Hench
Rochester, Minn.
My dear Dr Hench:
div1.p:
Many thanks for your
nice letter of Nov. 19, inclosing a
copy of your letter of Nov. 17. to
Mr Frederick L Rath, Jr.

We are very much interested in your
desire to preserve the Walter Reed
Building and will be glad to do
everything that we can to assist you.
The Association held the Annual
meeting on Nov 21. I will mail you
a copy of the minutes. Every one
was sorry that you were unable
to be present.

Mrs Kean allowed me to read your
letter to her with the copy of the
one to Mrs Standlee. you were
most kind to point out to Mrs Standlee
the unreliabilitys of some of her
sources of information. Unfortunately
I fear that you nor anyone else
is even going to be able to
change her opinion. She is
much like many of us, some of
whom, are so called historian,
very difficult to persuade that the
opinion that we have formed
is an incorrect one. I feel sure
that you will never be able to
convince her that Walter Reed
was deserving of the recognition
that has been givin to him. I
hope sincerely that she will never
be able to publish her distorted
version of his work.

Gen Streit assures me that she
will not. With best regard
